page.title: 11NATURE RESERVE IN BRADWELL
page.content: A nature reserve was set up in the grounds of{Woodlands Middle School}at the beginning of 1984. The headteacher, a keen conservationist, was concerned when mature trees were cut down near the school to make way for new homes. At the same time a row of elms were felled, killed by Dutch elm disease. A sponsored maths test raised over Â£1000. Then a part of the school field was ploughed up and during the year nearly 2400 trees were planted. A large pond has been dug which, it is hoped, will attract animals such as badgers, squirrels, rabbits, voles, mice and foxes. It is also hoped that many kinds of birds will use the area as a nesting site and many bird boxes have been put up.In the pond we hope to attract frogs, newts and toads.
